awd_titl_txt: Experiments on Turbulence-Chemistry Interaction in Highly Turbulent Counterflow Flames
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal: 1403433
PI: Gomez, Alessandro
Title: Experiments on Turbulence-Chemistry Interaction in Highly Turbulent Counterflow Flames

The proposal focuses on understanding how energy transfers occur in flames that are seen in practical burners such as power plants and jet engines.  A model flame, established by using the so-called counterflow burner, serves the purpose for investigation in a university laboratory, aiming to translate the knowledge gained into practical burner systems.   Advanced laser-based tools will be used in conjunction with a high-speed camera to visualize phenomena that are not seen by regular cameras and human eyes and that are of significance for understanding these flames. The proposed research is leveraged with collaborations with Sandia National Laboratory and Cornell University, where computer modeling of these flames will be pursued.  

The proposed study will focus on the assessment of the energy transfer across scales in highly turbulent counter-flow flames.  Turbulent kinetic energy is generated at large scales, transferred down in a cascade over a broad range of scales and eventually dissipated at the smallest scale.  Highly turbulent counter-flow flames will be used as a benchmark configuration for this type of systematic experimentation.  They offer significant advantages, such as: flame stabilization without a pilot at high Reynolds numbers; compactness, with significant advantages for highly resolved computations; and versatility, with the ability to access a broad range of combustion regimes, especially those of industrial relevance.  The objective is to quantify this energy transfer and contrast it in the non-reacting case with the reacting counterparts, under both non-premixed and premixed conditions.  A filter-space technique will be applied to a three-dimensional set of velocity measurements.  After initial tests at Yale to identify the most interesting flames, the bulk of the measurements will be performed at Sandia National Laboratories by relying on a newly acquired facility for high-speed imaging that will provide simultaneous tomographic PIV and planar laser-induced fluorescence measurements at high repetition rates. The proposed research is leveraged with collaborations with Sandia and Cornell University, where modeling of these flames will be pursued.  The proposed activity also has a computational component developed at Cornell that is validated using these experimental data. The high quality database, including well-characterized boundary conditions, will be made available on the web to the combustion community for further modeling within the framework of ongoing international collaborations.

por.por_cntn:
Turbulent combustion remains a major technical challenge affecting an industry of hundreds of billions of dollars that relies on combustion for power generation and propulsion. With the environmental impact of combustion being the focus of public opinion, compliance with regulatory restrictions and minimization of fuel consumption require a quantitative understanding of turbulent combustion. Such an understanding is of fundamental importance for the development of combustion systems performing 85% of energy conversion in America. Achieving this goal will assist in the development of the tools required for predictive modeling of such systems. For modeling to be reliable, systematic validation with an extensive experimental database is indispensable, a task for which practical, and inevitably complex, configurations are not as well suited as well-defined laboratory flames. The Yale turbulent counterflow system has been used as a benchmark configuration for this type of systematic experimentation. Through a collaboration between Yale and Sandia National Labs, with only the Yale component supported by NSF, a series of experiments on highly turbulent counterflow flames were performed at Yale and at Sandia. Studies were focused on conditions of local extinction/reignition, where the interaction of the turbulence and chemistry is most intense, over a broad range of conditions, including partial quenching and reignition. There was also a focus on energy transfer across scales relying on recently acquired diagnostic capabilities at Sandia: tomographic PIV, providing three dimensional and temporal information of the velocity field and OH planar laser induced fluorescence at high repetition rates.

A turbulent jet of lean-to-rich, CH4/O2/N2-premixed reactants at a turbulent Reynolds number of 1050 was opposed to a stream of hot products of combustion that were generated in a preburner. While the combustion product stream temperature was kept constant, its stoichiometry was varied independently from that of the reactant stream, leading to reactant-to-product stratification of relevance to practical combustion systems. We explored the role played by the chemical composition of the product gases that is typically overlooked by comparison with the stabilizing effect of the combustion product enthalpy that is critical in the mixing of reactants with hot products of combustion. The detailed structure of the turbulent flame front was analyzed in two series of experiments using laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) of multiple species: joint HCHO LIF and OH LIF measurements and joint CO LIF and OH LIF measurements. Figure 1 shows and example of flame front structure reconstruction in a counterflow flame. This type of information ultimately provides the primary heat release (lower left panel) and the forward reaction rate of the important oxidation reaction CO+OH--->CO2+H.

We found that critical combustion reaction rates were more readily quenched in the presence of products of combustion from a stoichiometric flame, whereas they were favored by lean combustion products. As a result, stoichiometric combustion products contributed to a greater occurrence of local extinction. In contrast, lean and rich combustion products facilitated flame ignition and stability and reduced the rate of local extinction. The influence of the combustion product stream on the turbulent flame front was limited to a zone of approximately two millimeters from the gas mixing layer interface of the product stream. Flame fronts that were separated from this interface by larger distances were unaffected by the product stream stoichiometry. A rationalization of these results that were published in a peer-reviewed journal was made using laminar flame calculations.

The second goal was an assessment of the energy transfer across scales, that is one of the fundamental questions in turbulent flows. By borrowing from numerical simulations, we can apply a filter-space technique to quantify the transport across scales of a given quantity, such as kinetic energy. The only constraint is that the data be sufficiently well resolved spatially and, possibly, three dimensional to account also for out-of-plane motion. We first collected tomo-PIV data at Sandia on cold jets and a jet flame, but there were considerable delays in performing experiments in counterflow because of frequent breakdowns of the high repetition rate laser diagnostics. In February 2016, after requesting a one-year no cost extension, we finally were able to perform experiments during a three-week experimental campaign. We collected a massive amount of data on a variety of nonpremixed and partially premixed flames, requiring no preheating of either opposed stream. Data analysis revealed that the three-dimensional data set is affected by beam steering. Therefore, we are now considering a subset of the data to obtain stereo-PIV information in addition to OH PLIF. A graduate student supported on discretionary funds of the PI is currently performing this task, despite the expiration of BSF support.

The high quality database, including well-characterized boundary conditions, is made available to the combustion community for further modeling within the framework of ongoing (inter)national collaborations, such as the Sandia-sponsored Turbulent Nonpremixed Flames Workshop.
